title: Jeremy Clarkson let slip the location for The Grand Tour season 4?
text:
The Grand Tour is going on the road for season four (Picture: @jeremyclarkson1/Instagram)

Jeremy Clarkson might have just revealed the location for The Grand Tour season four.

Fans are waiting patiently for the new episodes, which will see Jeremy, Richard Hammond and James May head off on a series of epic road trips to exotic locations.

While viewers are yet to find out where the Grand Tour trio will end up next, a comment from Jeremy on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire might shed some light on things.

Speaking to contestant Erica Roberts, Jeremy mentioned that he would be heading off on a holiday when she had to answer the question: ‘Khmer is the official language of which country – Laos, Bhutan, Malaysia or Cambodia?’

Having used up her ask the audience lifeline and unsure if her friends would know the answer, she turned to Jeremy.

The presenter explained: ‘Here’s what I think. Earlier this year I spent two or three months in south east Asia. Not Bhutan. I will be going to Bhutan in about six months.

Jeremy’s comment could mean that the guys have headed to Bhutan for the new episodes (Picture: Amazon)

‘Where have I been in the world? Literally everywhere is the answer to that, including Cambodia – I think on five occasions – where the official language is Khmer.’

While his answer was of course incredibly helpful to Erica, the part about travelling to Bhutan six months after the episode was recorded could mean that’s where he, Richard and James were headed to shoot new episodes of The Grand Tour.

Filming on the new season has also taken place in both Cambodia and Vietnam.

Things got pretty hairy for them out in Cambodia as the crew were caught up in a catastrophic monsoon and were forced to abandon filming for their safety.

metro-tag-post-strip]

Jeremy explained at the time that four people had been killed just ‘inches away’ from where they were recording just days before.

He has also detailed how the presenters and producers struggled to come up with locations that would be safe to film in.

In his column for The Sunday Times, Jeremy explained they had the idea to follow in the footsteps of Lawrence of Arabia from Saudi Arabia to Cairo.

He said: ‘This would be an epic journey, except it would mean crossing the Sinai peninsula and, thanks to Isis, the chances of us all arriving on the other side with heads were slim.’

He went on that the Andaman Islands, off the coast of Thailand, was also put forward, but ‘there’s a tribe on one of these islands that will kill anyone who lands.’

The Grand Tour is available to watch on Amazon Prime Video.
